titleStmt.title: Pamphilus saga : Upps DG 4–7 : A digital edition
titleStmt.editor: The Bergen group (1) University of Bergen

respStmt.resp: Project overview and finalising of XML file
Project overview and finalising of XML file

availability.p: Licence accepted by Odd Einar Haugen and by Robert K. Paulsen on behalf of the encoding group in a mail to Alex Speed Kjeldsen 9 November 2015.

notesStmt.note: Produced as part of a course in editing and annotating at the University of Bergen during the spring term 2015. The course was led by Odd Einar Haugen and Robert K. Paulsen.

sourceDesc.bibl: Photographic facsimiles of all three leaves (fol. 3r-5v) from the University Library in Uppsala.

origin.p: Written in Norway, probably in the Bergen area, c. 1270.

DG 4-7 now consists of 42 leaves in seven gatherings, each of originally 8 leaves. Thus, the complete manuscript once had (7 x 8) = 56 leaves. The first gathering lacks the middle pair and another leaf, which has been cut out. The second gathering also lacks the middle pair. The third and fourth gatherings are complete. The fifth gathering lacks the middle pair, and the sixth gathering lacks the fourth leaf, which has been cut out. The seventh gathering only has the outer pair of leaves. Remnants of the seventh gathering were found as the lining of a bishop’s mitra in Skálholt, and are now catalouged as AM 666b 4to in Copenhagen.

At the very beginning of DG 4-7, there are two leaves containing a fragment of "Óláfs saga Tryggvasonar". In the present state of the manuscript (and in the facsimile edition by Mattias Tveitane, 1972), they are fols. 1–2.

The main part of the manuscript are fols. 3–44, containing the initial two thirds of "Pamphilus saga", the concluding 13 lines of a dialogue between courage and fear, "Elis saga" and finally "Strengleikar". Note that in the facsimile edition and also in the present digital edition, the leaves have been numbered consecutively in the order they now have in the manuscript, irrespective of lost leaves and leaves which have been put in the wrong order as a result of the later binding of the book.
The information compiled here is based on the introduction in the facsimile edition by Mattias Tveitane (1972).

projectDesc.p: This manuscript text has been encoded according to the standard set out in The Menota handbook (version 2.0), at http://www.menota.org/HB_index.xml as of 2008-05-16.
The encoded text has numbered pagebreaks, columnbreaks and linebreaks according to the manuscript.

correction.p: This text has been transcribed directly from photographic colour facsimiles of the manuscript, and subsequently compared with the diplomatic edition by Ludvig Holm-Olsen (LHO) (1940). Emendations in the edition by Hermann Pálsson (HP) in "Gripla" vol. 6 (1984) have been added in notes, but the readings in the manuscript have as a rule been followed.

normalization.p: This text has been encoded on a diplomatic level.

interpretation.p: This text has not yet been annotated.

revisionDesc.change: 2017-06-06 Odd Einar Haugen University of Bergen: (1) Replaced all "me:punct" elements with "pc" elements as recommended in v. 3.0 of the Menota handbook; (2) Removed all 78 "pc type="supplied"" for hyphens supplied by the editor with nothing, as recommended in v. 3.0 of the Menota handbook and implemented in the latest version of the stylesheet used in the Corpuscle application, assuming that there are no examples of actual hyphens in the manuscript; (3) Made the file v. 1.0.7

2016-03-29
Odd Einar Haugen University of Bergen : (1) Changed the encoding of supplied hyphens from "supplied type="hyphenated"" to "pc type="supplied"" (for hyphens supplied by the editors, and lacking in the manuscript); (2) Made the file v. 1.0.6

2016-02-21
Odd Einar Haugen University of Bergen : (1) Revised the "availability" element in the header with a CC-BY-SA 4.0 licence; (2) Moved the "choice" element into the "w" element, and put the "sic" and "corr" elements within the "choice" element, i.e. "w" > "choice" > "sic" + "corr"; (3) Removed XML comments within notes so that the text of the note will be shown; and removed the "note" element around XML comments which are not supposed to be shown, such as comments on the space (or lack of it) between words; (4) Made the file v. 1.0.5

2016-02-18
Odd Einar Haugen University of Bergen : (1) In order to facilitate import in the Corpuscle application, the "sic" and "corr" elements are no longer brought together in a "seg" element, but in a "choice" element; (2) Made the file v. 1.0.4

2016-01-23
Odd Einar Haugen University of Bergen : (1) Replaced all 78 "me:punct type="supplied"" elements within "w" elements with "supplied type="hyphenated"" elements, so as to avoid having "me:punct" elements within "w" elements; (2) Made the file v. 1.0.3

2016-01-19
Odd Einar Haugen University of Bergen : (1) Added role="group" as an attribute to the "editor" element; (2) Made the file v. 1.0.2

2016-01-19
Odd Einar Haugen University of Bergen : (1) Changed the "msName" to "Pamphilus saga"; (2) Made the file v. 1.0.1

2015-03-19 Odd Einar Haugen University of Bergen: The "div" attribute type="chapter" was changed to type="annotation-chapter" to enable a separate display from the encoding in e.g. AM 242 fol; kept the file as v. 1.0

2015-03-04 Odd Einar Haugen University of Bergen: Described the first "div" level as "saga", the second as "chapter", and the third as "reply"; added space between the "oc" abbreviation and the following word (adding a note about this in each case), corrected some minor mistakes in the encoding; made the file into v. 1.0.

2015-03-04 Robert K. Paulsen University of Bergen: Corrected a number of readings on the basis of proofreading by the student group, added "div" elements for dialogue in the text and "s" elements for sentence division; made the file into version 0.9.2.

2015-02-20 Odd Einar HaugenUniversity of Bergen and Robert K. Paulsen University of Bergen: Compiled the text on the basis of individual transcriptions from the student group; gave the file version number 0.9.1.

s.note: HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "felur"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "hræring"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "þjónar"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "eg"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "fegurð"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is OEH.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "fegurðar"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is OEH.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "fæðir"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is OEH.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "stöpla"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "fæð"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "Léttlega"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "ei"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "kemur"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "kveðjur"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "æska"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "heimskar"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "ræðir"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is MNLJ.
Last "l" is written over an "a".
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "vanfædd"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "hlýði"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "Eg"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "minni"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "lítur"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "heimsku"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RT. RT disagrees with HP here, since "í móti" always governs the dative.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "ræmdur"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RT.
RT: Cannot see the reason for the ending "-a" in the emendation by HP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "fjáður"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
This reading is suggested by LHO in his edition.

p.note: Herman Pálsson emends the whole sentence to: "þó að eg eigi lítið, þá er mér lítið ærið".

s.note: HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "ærinn"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "frægð"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "félag"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is AR.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "óorð"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP emends this word to "ríkara" (i.e. "rikara"). However, in my experience, weak comparatives are not inflected in Old Norwegian, but have the ending "-ari" in all forms (RKP).
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "djarflegar"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has supplied the Modern Icelandic word "það"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "Eg"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
HP has emended this word to Modern Icelandic "ærist"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is OEH.
HP has emended this word to the Modern Icelandic phrase "Ást án"; responsible for the Old Norwegian form is RKP.
